reviewText: I'll always remember this movie for the shock of seeing a horse trying to live in an apartment. Now, there's an unusual sight!  By the way, I hadn't realized how nicely filmed this was until I saw it on 1.85:1 widescreen DVD. This is far better on disc than on VHS.Also to my surprise was that it wasn't the happy, family film I had remembered. There are many moments of frustration, sadness, violence, injustice, ete. It's hardly a bunch of fun times. Yet, when it's over and you reflect back on it, it's the comedy and warmth you remember.It's still a story, basically, about two kids trying to capture and then keep a white horse once they have him. (This was the one in the apartment!).  We go all over the Irish countryside as everyone, good and bad, try to find the boys and the horse. In between, their father slowly comes to grips with the death of his wife some seven years earlier, a tragedy he has never been able to deal with correctly.The best character and the most fun to watch is little "Ossie," played by Ciaran Fitzgerald. He's the one most-attached to the horse and the wee one has some of the best lines in the film.

reviewText: As far as I'm concerned, this 1992 movie is a classic. We wore our VHS version out, and had to buy the DVD.A mysterious white horse charges out of the sea and follows a Grandfather into Dublin, Ireland. It takes to the man's grandsons, Tito and and Ossie.  They call the horse Tir na nOg, the name of the Land Under the Sea, from where they believe he's come.Why did Tir na nOg (sounds like it's pronounced teer' un awg), Celtic horse of the otherword, decide to visit?  Why did it pick the boys?  This PG rated film is fine for children, but it is not just a kids' movie.  The boys are Travellers, Irish Gypsies, whose father has "settled"  -  not just literally, because they are living off the dole in the projects - but metaphorically.  The boys' Papa, in an outstanding performance by Gabriel Byrne, is a man bereft of dignity and pride, lost in the arms of alcohol since the death of the boys' mother. He had been King of the Travellers, and now he hates that he ever was one.This is a tale of redemption, of miracles. Of two young brothers who can face everything as long as they're together. There's even dramatic chase scenes, crooked cops, a venal business man  -  in other wise, great bad guys.Unfortunately, this DVD has no extras at all.  This is disappointing as there are so many possibilities for extra information. The horse (or horses) who played Tir na nOg is outstandingly elegant.  Who trained it, what kind is it, how did it take to filming?  Or how about more about the mythology?  Or a bit more about Travellers, past and present? Irish Travellers (there's two "l's") are not considered Rom, though the lifestyle is similar. More information on the music would be welcome, it was alternately stirring or plaintive.

reviewText: This plot is something of a modern fairy tale, but not necessarily for children. It's somewhat dark, rather bleak, and not what you should watch if you want happy imagery of Ireland. It has some really noble moments, but it's hard to believe this was ever marketed as a kiddo movie. Yes, it's a social commentary worth watching (and has some neat horse stunts as well), but it's not a horse flick you choose if you want a laugh a minute or light fare (instead go for a "Mr. Ed" feature).Since horses are historically crucial to Irish civilization and were held in high regard, the horse elements in this movie don't feel half as forced as some other horse movies out there. It's more like a story that happens to heavily involve horses. Horse racing, breeding, showing, and hacking still have a presence in that part of the world and probably always will. Gypsies (for lack of another concise word) with horses and caravans do still exist in Ireland, and their presence in this movie almost feels more like an observation than a praise or condemnation. It's interesting that although the heroes find some peace and redemption by returning to their roots (the story points out in a painfully plain way that living "rough" but free in the wild hills may be better than being in city projects), the gritty elements don't really get negated. The "bad guys" don't stop being bad and don't get conveniently banished away. The damage of years of psychological distance is still there by the ending, but there is a newfound family closeness that gives the boys cautious optimism. The horse serves as more of an intermediary than a friend, so there isn't a banal goodbye scene.The acting is generally rather good. David Kelly is genuinely enchanting and he's just the kind of storyteller you'd love to have as a grandfather. Gabriel Byrne is his usual quietly complicated self, and Ellen Barkin will make you smile with her quirky grin and lilting remarks. Ruaidhri Conroy and Ciaran Fitzgerald are perfect as the feisty but lonely Tito and Ossie. Brendon Gleeson consistently gives the right amount of grit and nastiness you expect out of a crooked cop in the bad part of town. The movie is also sprinkled with other familiar Irish and English faces.I first saw this movie when I was 10 years old and was able to handle the darker plot elements, but not every child is alike in maturity and intelligence. If you expect your young kids to watch it, do what the rating says and GIVE PARENTAL GUIDANCE while they watch it. The cultural differences between Irish and American life will puzzle and even alarm some viewers, as will certain speech details (the most basic knowledge of British English vocabulary will help you quite a lot). The character flaws may be above some little ones' understanding (example: "Papa" is not a bad man nor the villain, but he IS a bit scary, a bit disgusting, and a deeply depressed guy whose life is in a shambles). This film is surprisingly complex in some ways, and while that makes for a great "grown-up" fairytale, kids might just get upset by it.The ending will make you smile, but this film doesn't have a nice sugary coating along the way. I myself get slightly mesmerized when watching it (the excellent music soundtrack helps!) and its refusal to pull punches is partly why I keep watching it. This title is not as familiar to people as some other movies, so this may well be the one to get for your horse-loving friend who seemingly has every horse movie ever made.
summary: NOT for very young children, but still worthy watching

reviewText: This lovely film is a story about Travellers, about two boys and their father, and a horse that helps them get back to their roots. The horse's name is Tír Na n'Og, which is the ancient Celtic name for the islands in the west, the mythic Islands of Eternal Youth. The horse, emerging from the sea on the west coast of Ireland, seems to have a magical connection with the boys' late mother.

reviewText: This is a classic that will surely stand the test of time. It is also one of those rare movies that can be watched with equal enjoyment by adults and children. It appeals on both levels.I had no idea there were Irish gypsies before this movie, far less that they suffer prejudice. And the grittiness of the housing projects was an educational contrast to the usual "idyllic" view of Ireland. It spoiled a few illusions but I appreciated the realism. Some mythic images remain, however: I read that the story was inspired by the sight of a white horse on an upper floor of a Dublin housing project...which would never happen in America:)

reviewText: "Into the West" is an underrated jewel of Irish filmmaking that follows a rather unconventional storyline: a down-and-out father, Papa Reilly, (Gabriel Byrne), leads a miserable existence in a Dublin slum along with his two young sons.  The poverty and bleakness is overwhelming and not what one would expect from a Disney film (which it is).  Starving children sing on streetcorners for money, fathers drink away the welfare money, and education and sanitary conditions seem alien. This is not the Ireland of "The Quiet Man" or even "The Secret of Roan Inish."Papa Reilly is a traveller, or gypsy, although he has forsaken the old ways after his wife's death. His father-in-law tries to convince him in vain to return to the roads, but Reilly stands firm, insolently refusing all help. His two sons Tito and Ossie fall in love with a mysterious white horse that has followed their grandfather's caravan, and the two claim Tir na Nog as their own (but the horse had claimed them first). The lines between fantasy and reality are blurred, and this is not just a children's film, nor is it solely for an older audience. It is hybrid of mythology and magic much like "The Secret of Roan Inish," another Irish fairytale of a film that also dealt with magical animals (in that case seals).The rest of the movie requires suspension of disbelief, including several improbable chase scenes, but the heartwarming stories of the two boys coming to terms with their past (their mother's death, their father's alcoholism) and forging stronger bonds of brotherhood, and the grieving father and widower coming to terms with his loss and resolving to start a new life with his sons as the king of the travellers once more, truly make this a touching and unforgettable film.The scenery is beautiful, from the bleak, grey Dublin slums to the gently sloping western mountains, spectacular craggy cliffs and crashing seaspray. The soundtrack is a blend of Irish music old and new, with contributions from Black 47, the Rankin Family and Clannad. Patrick Doyle ("Shipwrecked") composed the score, which uses Irish instruments and haunting Irish Gaelic vocals to build atmosphere.There are several tense moments during action sequences which may prove frightening to younger children, but nothing overly objectionable in "Into The West." Younger children may find it a bit slow and hard to follow, but patience is truly a virtue in the case of this magical film.
summary: A magical family film that brings Ireland home....

reviewText: I was expecting this story to take place in the Western United States because of the title. To my delight, the movie opens up with a white horse galloping up and down a sandy seashore against the rolling green hills of Ireland, to the haunting sound of pipes. This is the magical story of two boys who dream of going out west(nevermind that there's a large ocean in the way). They and their father are each in their own way trying to deal with their poverty, the loss of their mother, and the stark contrast between life in the city and life on the road. Unlike other movies, where the horse is there just to decorate the cover, this lovely white horse is in practically every scene - yes, even in the apartment! Beautifully, solemnly, tenderly made, this movie is one that is worth seeing.
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Staci L. Wilson "Author: Animal Movies Guide ...
reviewText: Widower Papa Riley (Gabriel Byrne), once an important member of a nomadic tribe of travelers, now lives in the slums of Dublin with his two young lads, Ossie (Ciaran Fitzgerald) and Tito (Ruaidhrf Conroy), drinking himself to death. Their lowly lives take a wild turn when Grandpa Ward (David Kelly) brings them a magnificent (and possibly magical) white horse called Tir na Nog, but when the horse is taken away by the police, the family sets off across the old Emerald Isle to get him back. A great, stirring story for kids and adults.Staci Layne Wilson
summary: Horses, Magick, and a Little Blarney
